Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: A patient is recovering from a recent procedure and has slightly elevated vital signs.
Story: I stood in the cramped laundry room, sorting through a mountain of clothes, my phone buzzing insistently in my pocket. My husband had texted, reminding me that the kids needed clean uniforms for tomorrow’s school trip. I could almost hear his voice, gentle but firm, asking if I’d have time to finish the laundry before dinner. I wanted to be there, to help, to keep our home running smoothly. But just as I reached for the detergent, my work phone rang. It was the charge nurse—one of my patients, Mrs. Evans, was showing slightly elevated vital signs after her procedure. I was expected to come in, check her temperature, pulse, and blood pressure, and record everything immediately. My mind raced, torn between the pile of laundry and the urgent call from the hospital. Both needed me, both expected me to be present and responsible. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice between my family’s needs and my patient’s care.
